body.p: There are two type of data exists in NAND flash devices: static and dynamic. Static data is rarely updated, whereas dynamic data is constantly changing and requires frequent reprogramming. Dynamic data makes a particular block to be programmed and erased repeatedly without writing to any other blocks. That block would wear out before all the other blocks. The wearleveling algorithm distributes the writes as evenly as possible across all the flash blocks.

Wearleveling can be implemented using several methods, each of which adds complexity but increases the life of NAND flash devices. Lack of wearleveling can dramatically reduce the useful life of the NAND flash device. There are two kinds of wearleveling that can be implemented in the FTL.

li.p: When applying the dynamic wearleveling, new data is programmed to the free blocks that have the lowest erase count.
With static wearleveling, the context of blocks storing static data is copied to a block that has a high erase count, so that the original block can be used for data that is changed more frequently

body.p: The firmware implements a priority based algorithm for both static and dynamic wearleveling.
